reviewText: This series is about the exploits of the underground resistance against the Germans occupying France during WWII. It dramatically recounts how civilian men and women were trained by the British and sent to France as spies to assist the French Resistance forces. These recruits were drawn from British and foreign nationals who could pass themselves off as French locals and report covertly back to England information that would help the Allied war effort.Most were sent to France after a short, intensive training program. This would inevitably produce graduates who didn't have time to eliminate their personal flaws and these flaws would sometimes place them in great danger. That allows us to relate to the characters we meet, given their rudimentary training.The series follows characters that weave in and out of contact with each other throughout most of the series. Some are captured by the Germans, some escape; some meet back in England and then return to France. Their war is not frontline combat and so one would not classify this series as an action flick. Still, there are combat scenes when the Resistance attacks the Germans or is attacked by them, as was the case in  the war. Many of the British agents are women and the series helps you appreciate what dangerous circumstances confront them as they do their assigned task, sometimes with uncooperative men, sometimes with collaborators, in addition to being viewed at times as an inconsequential element by the conventional military forces.This is an important series because it covers an element of the war that is often overlooked; yet without the efforts of these agents, the Allied landings in Normandy would have been much more difficult.This is an engaging series that is an essential part of any library if one wants a comprehensive view of World War II.

reviewText: I loved "Wish Me Luck," but first let me comment on the three reviewers who gave it less than five stars."Irnbru" said the acting was the worst he's seen. That's just a matter of opinion; it didn't strike me that way. The actors did NOT look as though they were reading from a prompter. As for the accents, the British actors all had British accents, and the actors playing French citizens also spoke in English with a British accent. I don't see the problem.Reviewer "NY Baseball" rants about the women screaming. They don't scream often, and when they do, it doesn't seem to me to be out of the ordinary. In fact, if "NY Baseball" hadn't mentioned it in his review, I never would have noticed.Finally, reviewer "MaryLynne Larson" objects to the nudity. What nudity? I watched every minute of every episode, and I can assure viewers there is absolutely no nudity. There are a couple of bedroom scenes, but sheets and blankets completely cover the private parts of all of the actors and actresses.What made me want to watch the series was that it was thrilling. The characters were developed in a way that you cared about them, and they are in continual danger of being discovered by the Germans. The plot was not predictable.Acorn Media gives the viewer the option of subtitles, and I found I had to use that because the British accents were at times a little thick. "Two peoples separated by a common language," you know.Also, although I thought the series was thrilling, American viewers should keep in mind that the pace of "thrilling" to the British is slower than what we're used to. Be ready to spend some time, but you will be rewarded.

reviewText: Civilian women recruited and sent to Nazi-Occupied France for espionage & intelligence. Getting a job done takes a toll. Based on real women in Britain's Special Operations Executive (SOE). WWII fighting women did their part. DVD complete with fantastic period sets, costumes, scenery, and hair. Expertly done like "Foyle's War"Men & women train together to spy and survive. From London groups are sent to occupied France. Liz "Celeste" (code name) played by Kate Buffery is married, wealthy, with spouse in the African front. Matty "Aimee" (Suzanna Hamilton) low class, 1/2 Brit, 1/2 French, & 1/2 Jewish. Both speak fluent "Frog". Colin "Cyrano" (Jeremy Northam-"Emma") & gals meet Fr. Resistance leader Kit "Gregoire" (Michael J. Jackson- "Mobile"). London SOE head is Col. "Cad" Cadogan (Julian Glover) and you also see lots of Faith (Jane Asher). Spy-Liz (Kate Buffery-Trial & Retribution)....Spy Emily (Jane Snowden who reminds me of Honeysuckle Weeks)...Fr. Girl Sylvie (Shirley Henderson-The Way We Live Now)...Nazi Gen (Terrence Hardiman-Cadfael; Prime Suspect) and more.Setting up operations followed by receiving and sending data is crucial to the Allied war effort. It's touch-&-go work. Risks taken create plenty of suspense, intrigue, mystery, and a very realistic look into this special group of people from WWII. Who is helpful, who is the enemy, who can be trusted, where is safety, when and what is all addressed, but never the WHY? Each operation member has a personal reason & prepared to give their all......8 episodes in the Series 1 combine for one continuing story, one operation with some set-backs, losses, successes, and romance. Historical fiction done well--hard to forget it is not dramatized documentary. Plenty of sub-plots...... Series 2 even better than 1 with seven episodes. More military/spy action/fighting. Historically accurate war drama. Fantastic period viewing for 1940s London and France...... Series 3 is a French Alps set and a Frenchie, Nicole, helps when the Nazi nearly capture Emily traveling to join Kit. London's new SOE head, Faith, sends 2 spies to Le Crest, and the story goes on for 8 SUBTITLED episodes.SUBTITLES now for ALL 3 SERIES, THE "WISH ME LUCK: COMPLETE COLLECTION", I was able to confirm.Gritty to romantic, a superb mix of emotional lives behind the fighting lines in WWII. I'm glad I own it all.
summary: 1944 period perfect war and women spy suspense

reviewText: Harold Wolf "Doc" has a fantastic review!  I purchased this series based on his review.  I watched the first 4 episodes of series 1 in one evening!  I was completely engrossed in the story and the characters and did not realize that nearly four hours passed by!  Some critical reviewers were disenchanted with the acting and the music.  I think that the acting was superb!  I especially liked the character "Celeste" played by Kate Buffery and Faith played by Jane Asher.  Julian Glover's performance as Col. "Cad" Cadogan is also quite "spot on". The music was not at all annoying and I thought it was quite appropriate!  This series is very realistic and stays true to the history. According to Wikipedia, series 1 and 2 were based on the exploits of Nancy Wake, one of the most decorated servicewomen of the war.  She passed away in 2011!Nancy Wake: SOE's Greatest HeroineIt has sparked my interest to find out more about the S.O.E. operations and the fascinating history of these brave women (and men)! The definitive account seems to be M.R.D. Foots's book:SOE in France: An Account of the Work of the British Special Operations Executive in France 1940-1944 (Government Official History Series)Also of potential interest isFlames in the Field: The Story of Four SOE Agents in Occupied France.  I highly recommend this collection to anyone with an interest in World War Two and England.  I also must recommend Foyle's War!Foyle's War: Series 1-5 - From Dunkirk to VE-DayFoyle's War: Set SixandFoyle's War, Set 7.  I also enjoyedDanger UXB.

reviewText: Being an older film, it does not have the Hollywood film look. The characters are well developed.  The story chapters become adventures with new found friends. There is a realism to the WWII experience that is lost in more current films. The ruggedness of the sets enhances the viewers experience.  It is nice to see a story that celebrates the courage and intelligence of women during WWII.
